reviewText:
Developer: SnoutUp
Publisher: SnoutUp
Release Date: 27th January 2016
Platform:  Windows, Linux, OSX [Steam], iOS, Android, Windows Mobile
Price: Free

Disclaimer: The following review was conducted on PC via Steam.

A kung-fu fighting pig, I am not sure where this idea came from, but it seriously gets you in the mood for bacon!

IronSnout is a simple beat’em up game without horizontal movement where you play as a kung-fu fighting pig. You encounter a continuous stream of enemies which come in the form of wolves. This is referencing the Three Little Pigs and the Big Bad Wolf, one would assume.  The game play is simple to learn, but very challenging to become slightly good at.  The game is all about leader boards, competing against your friends and other players world wide. The more points you score from carrying out combos of strikes, and the longer you last before your Pig becomes bacon sandwiches all contribute to your final score.  You will find it tricky enough to break the one minute barrier most of the time, but when you do you soon come up against an increasingly challenging onslaught of wolves wielding axes, chainsaws, and riding rockets trying to be your end.

It is easy to see why this game has been released on so many platforms, but it is certainly a game more suited for either using a controller on for PC, or the touchscreen of phones. I tried playing using the keyboard controls and it is just a huge fumble-fest to say the least. Once trying to use the Xbox controller, you will see a noticeable difference in the way you are able to play the game.

Iron Snout’s art style is pleasantly presented in a simplistic cartoon form, nothing too fancy, and this is another element which makes it undoubtedly clear that this is a mobile port that has reached the PC platform. I personally would of liked to have seen a little variety in the background or maybe some different styles of enemies design being thrown at you rather than the same sprites over and over again. That being said, you can’t ask for much more from a free-to-play game.

If you like the sort of game where you can pick up and play for a few minutes and then put it back down again, then Iron Snout is going to tick that box for you, you’ll find it difficult to play this game for long periods of time, I think I maybe played it at most for 10 minutes at a time, any more than that and you’ll simply grow bored of the repetitive gameplay; but because of how quick it is to get into a game, and how quick games usually are to finish, this is the sort of game that has you keep coming back for more. The large amount of replay ability from this factor is definitely one of the strongest points from this title.

Although Iron Snout is a free to play game, it doesn’t come with all of the regular free to play baggage we have come to expect such as microtransactions or pay-wall barriers, this is simply put, a game that you can play to it’s full potential, for free - No hidden catches.  It’s worth a small amount of your time to try it out and experience it  for yourself. I for one have also downloaded this game onto my phone for that extra hit of Beat’em up bacon action on the go too. I urge you too, to try this little game out.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

reviewText:
TL;DR: Incredibly addicting little beat 'em up. Need to waste a couple of minutes? Play Iron Snout! It's free!

You're the Kung Fu Pig, the very pinnacle of self-defense. Instead of running away when murder-crazy cartoon wolves come at you, you punch them.

When they come, you smash them
Gameplay is very simple, yet challenging: arrow keys (or ASDW) left and right are attacks (the faster you hit buttons the faster you hit baddies), up is jump and down is crouch or dive. Wolves come at you at steady pace, few at first but then several at the same time and your task is to beat them all up before they kill you.

Various kinds of wolves carry items that can all be used against them. Butcher knives, hats and baskets can be thrown, and punching a wolf towards a rocket wolf explodes the whole bunch! Someone throws a knife at you that you can either deflect back with weapons or even grab and throw back to their face. The combo potential is great and fun to explore.

The challenge is the fact you can't move around. When two rockets are circling around and a wolf with a pongo stick is coming from one direction and a chainsaw dude and knife thrower from another, it's a feat to escape unharmed if they all come to the middle at the same time. In those situations you wish you could go and beat one side of enemies before the rest come at you.

Polished little gem
Actually the whole game is seen in few minutes, when you've seen all the seven enemy types and fought against a small horde of them at the same time. Still, it's addicting and fun to keep going for the highscores. 100% completion (achievement-wise) however takes roughly 5 hours because of a couple grindy cheevos.

It's polished and technically works great, assuming you can get over the cartoon graphics and the casual mobile vibe. It's very alt+tab-friendly so I found it convenient to play it at the same time as playing a clicker game in another window.

Rather miraculously it is totally free. I think it says something about the game that I wouldn't have minded paying a couple of bucks to play this.

reviewText:
Ok so I'm going to start off by saying this game is amazing.  I've attached a video if you want to check out some actual gameplay, but let me break down what I think about this game.

Iron Snout is very simple.  You click up, down, left, right, and that's it.  You kill wolves with punches, kicks, or by using weapons that you take from your killed foes.  The simplicity of the game comes from the fact that it is also for mobile devices.  Although simple there are many ways to kill the wolves or combo your attacks making the fighting even more interesting as you must react quickly to the oncoming enemies.  Every time I'd die, I'd want to keep going again and again to beat my highscore.  Sure there is only one mode and there's no upgrade system, but for being Free this game is absolutley amazing.  It's a must try, after all it's free.

Improvements that could be made are possibly different playable pigs, different backdrops or stages, more weapons or enemy times, or maybe even a power up system.  However for being free, it's great as is.  If things such as the ones listed were added, it deserves to have a price set.

Pros:
-Simple
-Fun art and animations
-Creative
-FREE (like seriously there's no shop or anything)
-Available for mobile

Cons (if any):
-Only one mode
-Only one background/stage

Check out some gameplay and feedback here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yyJjSsjEaNg

reviewText:
Let me start by saying that this feels like a very refreshing throwback to flash games, the kind I used to play in school, with just enough gore so that it would have been blocked in my school. I like games that I can pick up and put down in a moment's notice, so this suits my needs wonderfully.

The controls are elegant and simple. The rules are easy to remember: you are a pig ninja, wolves are jerks, kill wolves. It is simple enough so that you can immediately start having fun with it, while leaving room for style and improvement. I can see youtube gamers showing off their ridiculous high-scores for this game in the near future.

That being said, there is a reason this game is free-to-play. The whole game has two settings: normal and 1-hp. If you're not a psychotic perfectionist or from Korea, you will probably check out 1-hp setting, play it a few times, then go back to the normal setting forever.

Still, I can see this game eventually becoming something I would pay actual money for and I really hope the game makers will continue to update.

reviewText:
Iron Snout is a free game with colorful and cute graphics, goofy sound effects, and a simple yet addicting game concept.

When I first saw this game, I saw the intro video and fell in love with its simple and cute artwork. Soon after, I installed the game mainly to hear the hilarious sound effects and to throw a few wolves around. About 10 minutes in, I knew that I was going to be spending a lot more time on this game than I had planned.

This game offers a short and helpful tutorial at the beginning that you can play over and over until you master the controls. The controls that this game requires are used only by the arrow buttons. By hitting the arrows in a certain order, you can punch/kick (left and right attack) and spin to attack (upper and lower attack) as well as jump over(dodge) the wolves that are coming at you. After getting used to the controls, you can start to get fancy by grabbing the weapons from the wolves and turn around and use them to defend yourself or to kill them.

As you play, on the upper right of the screen, the game will keep track of how many wolves you killed in that match. After you lose all of your lives (displayed by pieces of bacon on the upper left of the screen), there will be a new screen that appears on the right that will display your match stats. It will display your length of the match, how many strikes you had, how many hits you had, your best combo, your number of weapon kills, your projectile kills, projectiles dodged, items you caught, and most importantly…the number of heads you knocked off.

Iron Snout is both comical and satisfying. I highly suggest giving it a try, especially because it is free! It is for gamers of all ages. Kids will enjoy the simplistic concept as well as the goofiness of the game. Older gamers will enjoy the ability to collect a variety of in game achievements as well as competitively aim for high combo kills. After a long day at work, this game is just what you want to play to unwind. You may even find yourself laughing to yourself and addicted just as I found myself.

reviewText: I have to say, this game is surprisingly addicting. It's WAY more addicting than it should be. It's actually fairly difficult as well, though mostly because certain attacks do more damage to your pig, which I think isn't really fair. All attacks should simply take off one slice of bacon from your meter, but that's just what I think. Anyways, it's very fast paced and once the enemies start coming more rapidly and frequently, you are forced to pull off much faster and much more ridiculous combos, of which look pretty cool. There are a few improvements I would like to see to this game to make it a bit better, and maybe give you an actual reason to keep playing. For one, I think an upgrades system could be well integrated into this game. For example, kills give you money, and then with that money you buy upgrades for your pig such as new attacks, combos take longer to dissapear, dual weilding weapons, attacks do more damage, triple jump, stuff like that. A few gamemodes, perhaps could work well. I want to see one that starts you off, as if you were at level 1000. Since the game gets progessively more chaotic and crazy as you kill more wolves, for example, at around 20 it's fairly chill, but begins getting pretty ridiculous at, say, 100. It should start you off immediately at a really high number, and maybe you have less health. Y'know, like a hard/cruel mode. It would let you see a lot of really cool combos, since there would be wolves coming from literally everywhere. So all in all, this is a surprisingly fun game, and it's free, so there's really no reason NOT to download it.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Finally, a game where I can be a badass and a cartoon-loving freak.

Introducing Iron Snout, a game where you star as a lovable little pig who makes a hobby of killing and decapitating the equally lovable wolves. Addicting gameplay, smooth graphics, and it's free and it has acheivements. Who the hell wouldn't get that?

It's simplistic, fun, and a good game to play if you're ever feeling bored. There's barely any lag, and with no currency as far as I know of, you won't be finding people at the top of the leaderboard just because they bought enough gems. This counts as major bonus points for me. Wouldn't you rather try to get to the top of the leaderboards in a nice, inexpensive way and not have people constantly beating you out because you have no money whatsoever? What's that? You have money? Get in line.

On the other hand, this game certainly has some drawbacks. For one, it is way too addicting. Sure, you laugh now, but just you wait. Soon you'll be among us, just one among the raging hordes of crazed ninja pigs that laugh in the face of an unending wolf army.

Yeah, yeah, I know. You started reading this review for serious issues. Y'know, like world ending bugs and all that jazz. Well, I can't really think of any, so you'll just have to deal with my own unimportant complaints.

The music is pretty meh. Standard and generic by any means, and I suggest plugging in some headphones and playing the songs that you prefer. Anything's fine, just make sure it compliments those sweet fighting techniques that your pig manages to pull off.

Customization is very limited as well, and it really isn't even there to begin with. I don't think they should go all out with gems and such, but maybe just add in a few costumes here in there that you can earn with each achievement. I myself don't endorse this, but I know I need at least two complaints or people'll start calling me biased or something. Which I am. You should get this game.

And now, to conclude this message, I shall end with the most generic and annoying thing to ever happen in a review.

11/10 would get humped by a mini-wolf again.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Finally, a game where I can be a badass and a cartoon-loving freak.

Introducing Iron Snout, a game where you star as a lovable little pig who makes a hobby of killing and decapitating the equally lovable wolves. Addicting gameplay, smooth graphics, and it's free and it has acheivements. Who the hell wouldn't get that?

It's simplistic, fun, and a good game to play if you're ever feeling bored. There's barely any lag, and with no currency as far as I know of, you won't be finding people at the top of the leaderboard just because they bought enough gems. This counts as major bonus points for me. Wouldn't you rather try to get to the top of the leaderboards in a nice, inexpensive way and not have people constantly beating you out because you have no money whatsoever? What's that? You have money? Get in line.

On the other hand, this game certainly has some drawbacks. For one, it is way too addicting. Sure, you laugh now, but just you wait. Soon you'll be among us, just one among the raging hordes of crazed ninja pigs that laugh in the face of an unending wolf army.

Yeah, yeah, I know. You started reading this review for serious issues. Y'know, like world ending bugs and all that jazz. Well, I can't really think of any, so you'll just have to deal with my own unimportant complaints.

The music is pretty meh. Standard and generic by any means, and I suggest plugging in some headphones and playing the songs that you prefer. Anything's fine, just make sure it compliments those sweet fighting techniques that your pig manages to pull off.

Customization is very limited as well, and it really isn't even there to begin with. I don't think they should go all out with gems and such, but maybe just add in a few costumes here in there that you can earn with each achievement. I myself don't endorse this, but I know I need at least two complaints or people'll start calling me biased or something. Which I am. You should get this game.

And now, to conclude this message, I shall end with the most generic and annoying thing to ever happen in a review.

11/10 would get humped by a mini-wolf again.

reviewText:
Super Fun pickup game that has very reasonable achievements.

Your pig can't move, and you have 4 buttons.
up, down, left, right.

the goal is to survive as long as you can.
the game gets progressively harder as you survive, typical of old school styled arcade games.

The catch is that, even though you can't move, you can still interact with items that enemies drop, and can perform actions with them. This leads to an interesting mix up alongside enemy patterns to develop a psuedo-strategy element in a fast paced button mashing extravaganza.

Not a very long game, but has replay value.
For it's length, it has a pretty good assortment of variable enemies and items.
Since it's free, it's well worth it to play.

I haven't that much time wracked up on this game on STeam, but I've been playing it for a looooong time on GameJolt and Android... and it's brilliant! The gameplay is deceptively simple, as you can do pretty well just by button mashing to start with, but after a few games you begin to realise that there is actually a LOT more depth to the controls... and once you get the hang of how the pig moves and the timings of the different wolves you'll find yourself plucking cleavers from mid air to hurl back at them and performing split kicks that would put Jean Claude Van Damme to shame.

Seriously, the game is slick as hell, fun to play and rather addictive, with that all important just one more game" factor set rather high. And it's free! So
recommended: you have no excuse not to play this little gem..."

It looks stupid and in some ways it is stupid but in a good way. This game deserves the same praise One Finger Death Punch got because it's honestly good and it's one great way to pass time, it's ♥♥♥♥ing free with achievements plus you get to reenact the three little pigs in a brutal 1 vs all to death, minus the 2 other piggies and add like... 100+ wolves!

This game does everything right in it's genre first off there's only one graphical option and that's for switching from windowed or to fullscreen it's up to you if you think that's a good point or not. The tutorial is super short like 5-10 seconds flat and without a hiccup you're straight into the game, the sound effects are pretty neat cute and simple. There's a couple of other options as well like turning off the music etc simple stuff. There is also plenty of enemy types to mix things up and in all honesty the game is not easy especially when you're further up the counter in the 100's. There's also no in-game shop or microtranactions it's straight up free nothing more nothing less and a big bonus is it's only like a 5-10mb game super small for what it is.

There's nothing really bad about the game it's free and fun... other than maybe having one graphical option? I also guess it wouldn't hurt to want to be able to customize the piggy but other than that the games pretty perfect no real complaints.

If you are or were a big fan of One Finger Death Punch then give this game a shot you won't be disappointed since it's straight up free, simple and fun!

reviewText:
I have almost all the achievements and just wanted to put my two cents about this game. This is an excellent time waster game.

Story:
There's really not much of a story. You play as a pig and you kill waves and waves of wolves that are after him for god knows what. But this game is really not about the story. But the main goal of the game is the get the highest score which you get one point every time you kill one wolf. You can also track and post your scores online and see how you are at the game with the rest of the world.

Gameplay:
This is where the game shines and is the reason you'll keep coming back. You control the pig with W,S,A,D, he can jump,duck,kick, and punch left, right and up.  The control is spot on and really satisfying to kill wolves. You also will be able to grab weapons from the wolves you kill, you can grab hats, chainsaws and more to add to your combo score much easier. All in all the gameplay is very fun and additive although can get repetitive if played in long sittings.

Graphics:
Very simple but very nice 2D art of the wolves and pigs for such a simple games the graphics look very nice and slick. But i wish there was more backgrounds to choose from than just the same tree only background.

Bottom line:

You really can't go wrong with this game. It's free, can get highly additive and is great fun for anyone looking to kill a few minutes before going somewhere. I say overall i would give it a download and is fun for any type of gamer looking for a fun quick game to play.
